title: الْحِكَايَةُ
description: Learn about الحِكَايَة - the grammatical phenomenon of quoting speech exactly as it was said, preserving original case endings and forms regardless of the new sentence structure.

notes.title: What is الحِكَايَة?
content: الْحِكَايَة (quotation/imitation) is a grammatical phenomenon where a word or phrase is quoted exactly as it was originally spoken or written, preserving its original form regardless of the grammatical position it occupies in the new sentence.
This means the quoted element keeps its original case ending (i'rab) even when the new sentence would require a different case. The quoted form is said to be مَحْكِيّ (quoted/imitated).
keyPoints: Preserves original form in new context
Original i'rab is kept, not changed

examples.english: 'Qum' is an imperative verb (word is quoted as-is)
I heard 'Alhamdulillah' (sentence quoted exactly)
I read 'In the name of Allah...' (quoted as-is)
I wrote 'Zayd is standing' (exact quotation)

notes.title: Quotation with Proper Nouns
content: One common type of حِكَايَة involves proper nouns that were originally in a different grammatical position. When asking about someone using مَنْ, the answer can preserve the original case of the name.

For example, if someone says رَأَيْتُ زَيْدًا (I saw Zayd - accusative), the questioner might ask مَنْ زَيْدًا؟ (Who is Zayd?), keeping the accusative form زَيْدًا even though مَنْ would normally take a nominative predicate.
keyPoints: Names quoted in their original case
مَنْ + اسم محكي: question preserves case

examples.arabic: قِيلَ: رَأَيْتُ زَيْدًا. فَقَالَ: مَنْ زَيْدًا؟
examples.english: It was said: I saw Zayd. He said: Who is Zayd?

examples.arabic: قَالَ: مَرَرْتُ بِزَيْدٍ. فَقُلْتُ: مَنْ زَيْدٍ؟
examples.english: He said: I passed by Zayd. I said: Who is Zayd?
I heard 'Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah'
I read Surah 'Al-Fatiha'

notes.title: Quotation of Sentences
content: Complete sentences can be quoted, becoming مَقُولُ الْقَوْلِ (the content of saying) or مَحْكِيّ. The entire quoted sentence maintains its internal structure while functioning as a unit in the larger sentence.
This is common after verbs like قَالَ (said), سَمِعَ (heard), قَرَأَ (read), كَتَبَ (wrote). The quoted sentence is في محل (in the position of) whatever grammatical role it plays.
keyPoints: Quoted sentence في محل its function

examples.english: He said: 'Allah is greater' (sentence quoted exactly)
I heard 'Glory be to Allah'
I read: 'And say: My Lord, increase me in knowledge'
He wrote: 'Knowledge is light'

notes.title: Quotation by Letter (الحكاية بالحرف)
content: الْحِكَايَةُ بِالْحَرْفِ refers to quoting something letter-by-letter or word-for-word exactly as it appears. This is the most precise form of quotation, preserving every detail of the original.
This is important when discussing language itself (metalinguistic use), citing sources exactly, or explaining grammar. The quoted element becomes a noun referring to itself.

examples.english: 'Daraba' is a past tense verb (quoting the word itself)
The letter 'ba' is a preposition
The word 'Allah' is the word of majesty
'Zayd stood' is a verbal sentence

notes.title: Grammar of Quoted Elements
content: When a word or sentence is quoted (مَحْكِيّ), it functions as a single unit in the larger sentence. The quoted element is في محل (in the position of) whatever grammatical role it plays - subject, object, etc.
The internal i'rab of the quoted element is not affected by its position in the new sentence. We say it is مَبْنِيّ عَلَى الْحِكَايَة (built on quotation).
keyPoints: في محل: in the position of its function
مَبْنِيّ عَلَى الْحِكَايَة: built on quotation

examples.arabic: «زَيْدٌ» اسْمٌ مَرْفُوعٌ - زَيْدٌ: مبتدأ محكي في محل رفع
examples.english: 'Zayd' is a nominative noun - quoted as subject

examples.arabic: قَرَأْتُ «الْفَاتِحَةَ» - الفاتحة: مفعول به محكي في محل نصب
examples.english: I read 'Al-Fatiha' - quoted as object

examples.arabic: سَمِعْتُ «نَعَمْ» - نَعَمْ: محكية في محل نصب مفعول به
examples.english: I heard 'yes' - quoted in accusative position

examples.arabic: كُتِبَ «لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللَّهُ» - الجملة محكية في محل رفع
examples.english: 'There is no god but Allah' was written - quoted sentence as subject

notes.title: Quotation in Classical Texts
content: Understanding الحِكَايَة is essential for reading classical Arabic texts, especially grammar books, tafsir, and hadith collections where exact quotation is crucial.
Classical grammarians used الحِكَايَة extensively when discussing Arabic language, citing Quranic verses, poetry, and hadith. Recognizing quoted elements helps avoid misunderstanding the grammar.
keyPoints: Used in tafsir and hadith citations

examples.english: Sibawayhi said: 'This is the chapter of...'
And in the hadith: 'Actions are but by intentions'
He Most High said: 'Read in the name of your Lord'
And from it is the poet's saying: '...'

exercises.prompt: الْحِكَايَةُ هِيَ نَقْلُ الْكَلَامِ كَمَا هُوَ مَعَ الْحِفَاظِ عَلَى _____ الْأَصْلِيِّ
exercises.promptEn: الحِكَايَة is quoting speech as-is while preserving the original _____

exercises.prompt: الْكَلِمَةُ أَوِ الْجُمْلَةُ الْمَنْقُولَةُ كَمَا هِيَ تُسَمَّى _____
exercises.promptEn: A word or sentence quoted as-is is called _____

exercises.prompt: قَالَ: «اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ» - الْجُمْلَةُ الْمَحْكِيَّةُ تُسَمَّى مَقُولَ _____
exercises.promptEn: He said: 'Allah is greater' - the quoted sentence is called مَقُولُ _____

exercises.prompt: رَأَيْتُ زَيْدًا. مَنْ زَيْدًا؟ - زَيْدًا فِي السُّؤَالِ _____ عَلَى مَا سُمِعَ
exercises.promptEn: I saw Zayd. Who is Zayd? - زَيْدًا in the question is _____ as it was heard

exercises.prompt: الْحِكَايَةُ بِالْحَرْفِ تَعْنِي نَقْلَ الْكَلَامِ حَرْفًا بِ_____ بِدِقَّةٍ
exercises.promptEn: الحِكَايَة بِالْحَرْفِ means quoting speech letter by _____ precisely

exercises.prompt: «ضَرَبَ» فِعْلٌ مَاضٍ - كَلِمَةُ ضَرَبَ هُنَا _____ لِلدَّلَالَةِ عَلَى نَفْسِهَا
exercises.promptEn: 'Daraba' is a past verb - the word ضَرَبَ here is _____ to refer to itself

exercises.prompt: A word that is quoted and preserves its original grammatical form
The grammatical phenomenon of preserving original case when quoting
